name: ENT Infections (Ear, Nose, Throat)
description: Bacterial and viral infections of the ear, nose, and throat including pharyngitis, otitis media, sinusitis, and deep neck infections

conditions.name: Group A Streptococcal Pharyngitis (Strep Throat)
conditions.shortDescription: Bacterial pharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus requiring antibiotics to prevent rheumatic fever and suppurative complications

content.definition: Bacterial pharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes). Antibiotics prevent acute rheumatic fever (ARF, 0.3-3% if untreated), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN, 10-15%), and suppurative complications (peritonsillar abscess 1-2%, retropharyngeal abscess <1%). Most pharyngitis is viral (70-80%), antibiotics NOT indicated.
content.clinical_presentation: Acute onset of sore throat, fever (>38°C), tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, absence of cough. Centor criteria (4 points): Fever (1), Tonsillar exudates (1), Tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (1), Absence of cough (1). Score 0-1: Viral likely (no testing). Score 2-3: Test (rapid strep or culture). Score 4: Treat empirically OR test.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical diagnosis + Rapid antigen detection test (RADT) OR Throat culture. RADT sensitivity 70-90%, specificity 95-99%. If RADT negative in children → throat culture (backup, sensitivity 90-95%). Adults: RADT negative → no culture needed (low ARF risk).
red_flags: Stridor or drooling - suggests epiglottitis or retropharyngeal abscess, airway emergency, urgent ENT referral
Trismus (difficulty opening mouth) - suggests peritonsillar abscess, ENT referral for drainage
Muffled voice or hot potato voice - suggests peritonsillar abscess, ENT referral
Severe dysphagia or inability to swallow - suggests deep neck infection, CT neck + ENT referral
Unilateral tonsillar swelling - suggests peritonsillar abscess, ENT referral

content.when_to_test: Centor score 2-4: Test with RADT OR Throat culture. Centor score 0-1: Do NOT test (viral likely, antibiotics NOT indicated). Do NOT test if clear viral features (cough, rhinorrhea, hoarseness, conjunctivitis, diarrhea).
essential_tests: Rapid antigen detection test (RADT): Sensitivity 70-90%, specificity 95-99%. Results in 5-10 minutes. If positive → treat. If negative in children → throat culture (backup). If negative in adults → no culture needed.
Throat culture: Gold standard. Sensitivity 90-95%, specificity 99%. Results in 24-48 hours. Indicated if: RADT negative in children, RADT unavailable, or high suspicion despite negative RADT.
conditional_tests: ASO titer (anti-streptolysin O): NOT indicated for acute pharyngitis (rises 3-6 weeks post-infection). Use for suspected ARF or PSGN.
Monospot or EBV serology: If suspected infectious mononucleosis (posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, atypical lymphocytes).
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT test if: Centor score 0-1, clear viral features (cough, rhinorrhea, hoarseness, conjunctivitis), or asymptomatic contacts (test of cure NOT indicated).

content.organism: Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes). Gram-positive cocci in chains. Beta-hemolytic. Lancefield group A. Produces streptolysin O (ASO), streptolysin S, hyaluronidase, DNase, streptokinase. M protein (virulence factor, >200 serotypes).
content.pathogenesis: Droplet transmission → pharyngeal colonization → local invasion → pharyngitis. Complications: Suppurative (peritonsillar abscess, retropharyngeal abscess, cervical lymphadenitis, otitis media, sinusitis, mastoiditis). Non-suppurative (acute rheumatic fever ARF 0.3-3%, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis PSGN 10-15%).

resistance_patterns.penicillin: Penicillin resistance: NONE. GAS remains 100% susceptible to penicillin (NO resistance reported worldwide).
resistance_patterns.macrolides: Macrolide resistance (erythromycin, azithromycin): 5-15% in US, up to 30-40% in some regions (Asia, Europe). Use penicillin or amoxicillin as first-line.

content.timing_critical: Start antibiotics within 9 days of symptom onset to prevent ARF (antibiotics effective up to 9 days). Earlier treatment (within 24-48 hours) reduces symptom duration by 1-2 days and reduces transmission.

content.first_line_adults: Penicillin VK 500mg PO TID x 10 days OR Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID x 10 days (preferred, better compliance, once-daily dosing NOT recommended). Alternative: Amoxicillin 1000mg PO once daily x 10 days (IDSA 2025 NEW, non-inferior to TID dosing).
content.first_line_children: Amoxicillin 50mg/kg/day PO divided BID x 10 days (max 1000mg/dose) OR Penicillin VK 250mg PO BID-TID x 10 days (weight <27kg) OR 500mg PO BID-TID x 10 days (weight ≥27kg).
content.penicillin_allergy_non_anaphylactic: Cephalexin 500mg PO BID x 10 days (adults) OR 25mg/kg/day PO divided BID x 10 days (children, max 500mg/dose). Safe if non-anaphylactic penicillin allergy (rash only, no anaphylaxis).
content.penicillin_allergy_anaphylactic: Azithromycin 500mg PO x1, then 250mg PO daily x 4 days (total 5 days, adults) OR 12mg/kg PO daily x 5 days (children, max 500mg/dose). Alternative: Clindamycin 300mg PO TID x 10 days (adults) OR 20mg/kg/day PO divided TID x 10 days (children, max 300mg/dose).
content.avoid_list: Avoid fluoroquinolones (NOT indicated for pharyngitis, reserve for serious infections). Avoid TMP-SMX (NOT effective against GAS). Avoid short-course therapy <10 days (except azithromycin 5 days, higher ARF risk with <10 days penicillin/amoxicillin).

content.group_a_streptococcus: Penicillin VK 500mg PO TID x 10 days OR Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID x 10 days OR Amoxicillin 1000mg PO once daily x 10 days (IDSA 2025 NEW). Alternative: Benzathine penicillin G 1.2 million units IM x1 (adults) OR 600,000 units IM x1 (children <27kg) OR 1.2 million units IM x1 (children ≥27kg). IM penicillin: Guaranteed compliance, painful injection, use if compliance concern.
content.penicillin_allergy: Cephalexin 500mg PO BID x 10 days (non-anaphylactic allergy) OR Azithromycin 500mg PO x1, then 250mg PO daily x 4 days (anaphylactic allergy) OR Clindamycin 300mg PO TID x 10 days (anaphylactic allergy).
content.treatment_failure: Persistent symptoms after 48-72 hours of antibiotics. Causes: Non-compliance, resistant organism (macrolides 5-15%), viral pharyngitis (antibiotics NOT effective), peritonsillar abscess. Management: Repeat RADT/culture, switch to clindamycin 300mg PO TID x 10 days (better eradication, covers beta-lactamase producing organisms), or benzathine penicillin G IM x1 (compliance).
content.carrier_state: Asymptomatic GAS colonization (10-20% of children, 5-10% of adults). Do NOT treat carriers (no ARF risk, antibiotics NOT effective at eradication). Indications to treat carrier: Outbreak in closed community, family history of ARF, multiple documented GAS infections, or tonsillectomy planned. Treatment: Clindamycin 300mg PO TID x 10 days OR Rifampin 600mg PO daily x 4 days + Penicillin VK 500mg PO TID x 10 days.
content.duration: 10 days for penicillin/amoxicillin (shorter duration increases ARF risk). 5 days for azithromycin (adequate). 10 days for cephalexin/clindamycin.
content.test_of_cure: NOT indicated (asymptomatic carriers common, no ARF risk). Exception: Recurrent GAS pharyngitis (3+ episodes in 6 months) → consider tonsillectomy.

content.standard_duration: 10 days for penicillin/amoxicillin/cephalexin/clindamycin. 5 days for azithromycin. Shorter duration (<10 days) for penicillin/amoxicillin increases ARF risk (0.3-3% if untreated, <0.1% if treated 10 days).
content.monitoring: Improvement expected in 24-48 hours (decreased fever, decreased sore throat). If no improvement → repeat RADT/culture, consider treatment failure (switch to clindamycin or IM penicillin), or peritonsillar abscess (ENT referral).
content.stop_criteria: Complete 10 days even if symptoms resolve earlier (prevent ARF and PSGN). Return to school/work 24 hours after starting antibiotics (no longer contagious).

content.recurrent_pharyngitis: 3+ episodes in 6 months OR 5+ episodes in 12 months. Causes: Reinfection (household contacts), carrier state, non-GAS pharyngitis (viral). Management: Treat household contacts if symptomatic, consider tonsillectomy (AAO-HNS 2019 criteria: 7+ episodes in 1 year, 5+ episodes/year x 2 years, or 3+ episodes/year x 3 years).
content.peritonsillar_abscess: Complication of GAS pharyngitis (1-2%). Unilateral tonsillar swelling, uvula deviation, trismus, muffled voice. CT neck with contrast OR clinical diagnosis. Needle aspiration or I&D (ENT performs) + Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID x 10 days OR Clindamycin 300mg PO TID x 10 days. Admit if: Severe, airway compromise, unable to tolerate PO.
content.scarlet_fever: GAS pharyngitis + erythematous sandpaper-like rash (exotoxin-mediated). Rash starts on trunk, spreads to extremities, spares palms/soles. Strawberry tongue, Pastia lines (petechiae in skin folds). Treatment: Same as GAS pharyngitis (penicillin or amoxicillin x 10 days). Rash resolves in 3-5 days, desquamation (peeling) in 1-2 weeks.
content.pregnancy: Penicillin VK or amoxicillin safe (Category B). Avoid azithromycin (Category B, but limited data). Avoid fluoroquinolones (Category C, teratogenic).
content.infectious_mononucleosis: EBV pharyngitis. Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, atypical lymphocytes. Avoid amoxicillin/ampicillin (causes morbilliform rash in 90-100% of EBV patients). Treatment: Supportive care (antibiotics NOT indicated). Avoid contact sports x 3-4 weeks (splenic rupture risk).
content.rheumatic_fever_prevention: Antibiotics within 9 days of symptom onset prevent ARF (0.3-3% if untreated, <0.1% if treated). ARF: Carditis (60-70%, permanent valve damage), polyarthritis (70-80%), chorea (10-15%), erythema marginatum (5-10%), subcutaneous nodules (5-10%). Jones criteria for diagnosis.

de_escalation_opportunities: Do NOT treat if Centor score 0-1 (viral likely, antibiotics NOT indicated)
Do NOT treat if RADT negative in adults (no culture needed, low ARF risk)
Do NOT treat asymptomatic carriers (no ARF risk, antibiotics NOT effective)
Do NOT perform test of cure (asymptomatic carriers common, no ARF risk)
timeout_checklist: Is Centor score ≥2? (If 0-1 → do NOT test or treat, viral likely)
Is RADT or throat culture positive? (If negative in adults → do NOT treat)
Are antibiotics started within 9 days? (Prevent ARF, effective up to 9 days)
Is duration 10 days? (Shorter duration increases ARF risk)
Is penicillin or amoxicillin used? (First-line, GAS 100% susceptible)
Is patient educated about return to school/work? (24 hours after starting antibiotics)
Is patient educated about completing 10 days? (Prevent ARF and PSGN)
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Avoid antibiotics if: Centor score 0-1, clear viral features (cough, rhinorrhea, hoarseness, conjunctivitis), RADT negative in adults, or asymptomatic carrier. Most pharyngitis is viral (70-80%), antibiotics NOT indicated. Antibiotics reduce symptom duration by only 1-2 days, but prevent ARF (0.3-3% if untreated).
content.diagnostic_stewardship: Use Centor criteria to guide testing. Do NOT test if Centor score 0-1. Do NOT culture if RADT negative in adults. Do NOT perform test of cure.
content.prevention: Hand hygiene. Avoid sharing utensils, cups, or toothbrushes. Cover cough/sneeze. Return to school/work 24 hours after starting antibiotics.

AAO-HNS Clinical Practice Guideline: Tonsillectomy in Children (2019)

conditions.name: Acute Otitis Media (AOM)
conditions.shortDescription: Bacterial infection of the middle ear requiring antibiotics in children <2 years or severe cases

content.definition: Bacterial infection of the middle ear. Most common in children (peak age 6-24 months). Complications: Tympanic membrane perforation (5-10%), mastoiditis (<1%), meningitis (<0.1%). Watchful waiting (observation without antibiotics) appropriate in select cases (age >2 years, mild symptoms, unilateral).
content.clinical_presentation: Acute onset of ear pain (otalgia), fever, irritability, decreased hearing. Otoscopic findings: Bulging tympanic membrane (TM), decreased TM mobility (pneumatic otoscopy), middle ear effusion, erythema. Diagnostic criteria (AAP 2013): Moderate-severe bulging TM OR New onset otorrhea (not due to otitis externa) OR Mild bulging TM + recent onset ear pain (<48 hours) or intense TM erythema.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical diagnosis by otoscopy. Pneumatic otoscopy (decreased TM mobility) confirms middle ear effusion. Tympanometry if diagnosis uncertain (flat Type B curve suggests effusion).
red_flags: Mastoiditis - postauricular swelling, erythema, tenderness, protrusion of auricle, requires IV antibiotics + ENT referral
Meningitis - fever, headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status, requires LP + IV antibiotics
Facial nerve palsy - suggests temporal bone involvement, requires IV antibiotics + ENT referral
Persistent otorrhea >3 months - suggests chronic suppurative otitis media, requires ENT referral

content.when_to_test: Clinical diagnosis by otoscopy. Pneumatic otoscopy (decreased TM mobility) confirms middle ear effusion. Tympanometry if diagnosis uncertain.
essential_tests: Otoscopy: Bulging TM, decreased TM mobility, middle ear effusion, erythema. Pneumatic otoscopy (gold standard, decreased TM mobility confirms effusion).
Tympanometry: Flat Type B curve suggests middle ear effusion. Use if diagnosis uncertain or unable to visualize TM (cerumen impaction).
conditional_tests: Tympanocentesis (needle aspiration of middle ear fluid): If severe, immunocompromised, failed therapy, or neonatal. Culture middle ear fluid. ENT performs.
CT temporal bone: If suspected mastoiditis or intracranial complication (meningitis, brain abscess).
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT obtain blood cultures (low yield, not indicated). Do NOT obtain CT routinely (clinical diagnosis).
content.turnaround_time: Otoscopy: Immediate. Tympanometry: Immediate. Tympanocentesis culture: 24-48 hours. CT: <1 hour.

content.organism: Streptococcus pneumoniae (30-40%), Haemophilus influenzae non-typeable (20-30%), Moraxella catarrhalis (10-15%), Group A Streptococcus (5-10%). Viral coinfection common (RSV, influenza, rhinovirus 40-60%).
content.pathogenesis: Viral URI → Eustachian tube dysfunction → negative middle ear pressure → bacterial colonization from nasopharynx → AOM. Children at higher risk (shorter, more horizontal Eustachian tube).

resistance_patterns.penicillin_resistance: S. pneumoniae: Penicillin-resistant 30-40% (MIC >2 mcg/mL). High-dose amoxicillin (80-90mg/kg/day) overcomes resistance.
resistance_patterns.beta_lactamase: H. influenzae: Beta-lactamase producing 30-50%. M. catarrhalis: Beta-lactamase producing 90-100%. Amoxicillin-clavulanate effective.

content.timing_critical: Antibiotics within 24-48 hours if: Age <6 months, age 6-24 months with bilateral AOM or severe symptoms, or age ≥24 months with severe symptoms. Watchful waiting (observation 48-72 hours) if: Age ≥24 months, unilateral, mild symptoms, reliable follow-up.

content.first_line_children: Amoxicillin 80-90mg/kg/day PO divided BID x 5-10 days (high-dose, overcomes penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae). Duration: 10 days if age <2 years or severe. 5-7 days if age ≥2 years and mild-moderate.
content.first_line_adults: Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID x 5-7 days OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID x 5-7 days (if recent antibiotic use or failed amoxicillin).
content.amoxicillin_failure_or_recent_use: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 90mg/kg/day amoxicillin component PO divided BID x 10 days (children) OR 875mg PO BID x 7-10 days (adults). Covers beta-lactamase producing H. influenzae and M. catarrhalis.
content.penicillin_allergy_non_anaphylactic: Cefdinir 14mg/kg/day PO divided BID x 10 days (children) OR 300mg PO BID x 5-7 days (adults). Safe if non-anaphylactic penicillin allergy.
content.penicillin_allergy_anaphylactic: Azithromycin 10mg/kg PO x1, then 5mg/kg PO daily x 4 days (children) OR 500mg PO x1, then 250mg PO daily x 4 days (adults). Alternative: Levofloxacin 10-20mg/kg PO daily x 10 days (children >6 months) OR 500mg PO daily x 7-10 days (adults).
content.watchful_waiting: Observation without antibiotics x 48-72 hours if: Age ≥24 months, unilateral, mild symptoms (ear pain <48 hours, temperature <39°C), reliable follow-up. Provide analgesics (ibuprofen or acetaminophen). Start antibiotics if: No improvement in 48-72 hours or worsening symptoms.
content.avoid_list: Avoid TMP-SMX (resistance 20-30%, NOT first-line). Avoid cephalexin (inadequate coverage for H. influenzae and M. catarrhalis). Avoid fluoroquinolones in children <6 months (cartilage toxicity).

content.s_pneumoniae_penicillin_susceptible: Amoxicillin 80-90mg/kg/day PO divided BID x 5-10 days (children) OR 500mg PO TID x 5-7 days (adults).
content.s_pneumoniae_penicillin_resistant: Amoxicillin 80-90mg/kg/day PO divided BID x 10 days (high-dose overcomes resistance) OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 90mg/kg/day amoxicillin component PO divided BID x 10 days.
content.h_influenzae_or_m_catarrhalis: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 90mg/kg/day amoxicillin component PO divided BID x 10 days (children) OR 875mg PO BID x 7-10 days (adults). Covers beta-lactamase producing organisms.
content.treatment_failure: Persistent symptoms after 48-72 hours of antibiotics. Causes: Resistant organism, non-compliance, viral URI (antibiotics NOT effective). Management: Switch to amoxicillin-clavulanate 90mg/kg/day PO BID x 10 days OR Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IM/IV daily x 3 days. If still failing → tympanocentesis (culture middle ear fluid) + ENT referral.
content.recurrent_aom: 3+ episodes in 6 months OR 4+ episodes in 12 months. Management: Prophylactic antibiotics NOT recommended (AAP 2013, increases resistance). Consider tympanostomy tubes (ENT referral) if: Recurrent AOM with persistent effusion, hearing loss, or speech delay.
content.duration: 10 days if age <2 years or severe. 5-7 days if age ≥2 years and mild-moderate. Shorter duration (5-7 days) non-inferior in older children with uncomplicated AOM.

content.standard_duration: 10 days if age <2 years or severe. 5-7 days if age ≥2 years and mild-moderate. Shorter duration (5-7 days) non-inferior in older children with uncomplicated AOM.
content.monitoring: Improvement expected in 48-72 hours (decreased ear pain, decreased fever). If no improvement → switch to amoxicillin-clavulanate or ceftriaxone IM x 3 days. Follow-up in 2-3 months to assess for persistent middle ear effusion (otitis media with effusion OME, 40-60% after AOM).
content.stop_criteria: Complete 5-10 days (based on age and severity). Persistent middle ear effusion (OME) after AOM is common (40-60%), resolves spontaneously in 3 months (90%), antibiotics NOT indicated for OME.

content.tympanic_membrane_perforation: Spontaneous TM perforation with otorrhea (5-10% of AOM). Treatment: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 90mg/kg/day PO BID x 10 days + Topical ciprofloxacin-dexamethasone otic drops BID x 7 days (if otorrhea). Avoid ototoxic drops (aminoglycosides, neomycin) if TM perforation. TM heals spontaneously in 90% within 2-4 weeks.
content.mastoiditis: Complication of AOM (<1%). Postauricular swelling, erythema, tenderness, protrusion of auricle. CT temporal bone (confirm diagnosis, assess abscess). IV antibiotics: Vancomycin 15mg/kg IV q12h + Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IV q12h x 2-4 weeks. ENT referral for myringotomy ± mastoidectomy if abscess or failed medical therapy.
content.recurrent_aom: 3+ episodes in 6 months OR 4+ episodes in 12 months. Prophylactic antibiotics NOT recommended (increases resistance). Consider tympanostomy tubes (ENT referral) if: Recurrent AOM with persistent effusion, hearing loss, or speech delay.
content.otitis_media_with_effusion_ome: Persistent middle ear effusion without acute infection. Common after AOM (40-60%), resolves spontaneously in 3 months (90%). Antibiotics NOT indicated. Observation x 3 months. If persistent >3 months with hearing loss → ENT referral for tympanostomy tubes.
content.neonatal_aom: Age <28 days. Higher risk of serious bacterial infection (meningitis, sepsis). Admit for IV antibiotics: Ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q8h + Cefotaxime 50mg/kg IV q8h x 10 days. Blood cultures, LP if febrile.
content.immunocompromised: Higher risk of complications (mastoiditis, meningitis). Admit for IV antibiotics: Vancomycin 15mg/kg IV q12h + Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IV q12h x 10-14 days. Tympanocentesis (culture middle ear fluid).

de_escalation_opportunities: Watchful waiting (observation 48-72 hours) if: Age ≥24 months, unilateral, mild symptoms, reliable follow-up
Shorter duration (5-7 days) if: Age ≥2 years and mild-moderate (non-inferior to 10 days)
Do NOT use prophylactic antibiotics for recurrent AOM (increases resistance, NOT recommended)
Do NOT treat otitis media with effusion (OME) with antibiotics (resolves spontaneously in 90% within 3 months)
timeout_checklist: Is diagnosis confirmed by otoscopy? (Bulging TM, decreased TM mobility, middle ear effusion)
Is watchful waiting appropriate? (Age ≥24 months, unilateral, mild symptoms, reliable follow-up)
Is high-dose amoxicillin used? (80-90mg/kg/day, overcomes penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae)
Is duration appropriate? (10 days if age <2 years or severe, 5-7 days if age ≥2 years and mild-moderate)
Is follow-up arranged? (2-3 months to assess for persistent OME)
Is analgesic prescribed? (Ibuprofen or acetaminophen for ear pain)
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Avoid antibiotics if: Watchful waiting appropriate (age ≥24 months, unilateral, mild symptoms). Avoid prophylactic antibiotics for recurrent AOM (increases resistance). Avoid antibiotics for OME (resolves spontaneously). Avoid ototoxic drops (aminoglycosides, neomycin) if TM perforation.
content.diagnostic_stewardship: Use pneumatic otoscopy to confirm diagnosis (decreased TM mobility). Tympanometry if diagnosis uncertain. Do NOT obtain blood cultures (low yield). Do NOT obtain CT routinely (clinical diagnosis).
content.prevention: Pneumococcal vaccine (PCV13, reduces AOM by 6-7%). Influenza vaccine (reduces AOM by 30%). Breastfeeding (protective). Avoid pacifier use after 6 months. Avoid tobacco smoke exposure.
